channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Interpreter: How Britain Could Exit ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: A souvenir stall in central London on Sunday. Technically, the “Brexit” referendum result is not legally binding.
item.description: The country has a few options for how it might remain in the European Union. Each carries significant risks — but, then again, so does leaving.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: With ‘Brexit,’ Washington’s Direct Line to the Continent Suddenly Frays
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Paolo Gentiloni, the Italian foreign minister, in Rome on Sunday.
item.description: Officials say no country shares the United States’ worldview quite the way Britain does in terms of security, intelligence and trade.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Fractures From ‘Brexit’ Vote Spread Into Opposition Labour Party
item.media:description: Hilary Benn, the shadow foreign secretary for the Labour Party, leaves his home in London on Sunday after he was fired.
item.description: Internal criticism of the leader, Jeremy Corbyn, led to his firing the shadow foreign secretary, and at least 11 other members of the party’s cabinet resigned.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Spain’s Vote Deals Setback to Podemos, a Rising Protest Party
item.media:description: Mariano Rajoy, Spain’s caretaker prime minister, during a news conference on Monday. His Popular Party won the most votes in Sunday’s election, halting advances made by the left-wing Podemos party.
item.description: The radical left-wing party fell short of expectations in Sunday’s election as the Popular Party of Mariano Rajoy won the most votes.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Diplomatic Deal With Turkey Upsets Israelis Wary of Conceding Too Much
item.media:description: One of several Israeli assault boats pulled alongside the Turkish passenger ship Mavi Marmara during a 2010 raid by Israeli naval commandos, the episode that set off the diplomatic crisis between the once-close regional allies.
item.media:credit: Kate Geraghty/Sydney Morning Herald, via Getty Images
item.description: Israel will pay $20 million to families of activists killed during an Israeli raid and will allow aid to enter Gaza, but the bodies of two Israeli soldiers will not be returned.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: ISIS Is Said to Claim Responsibility for Attack at Jordan-Syria Border
item.media:description: The Ruqban refugee camp in Jordan’s northeast border. The Jordanian government responded to a suicide attack last week by sealing its borders with Syria.
item.description: The assault last week killed seven members of the Jordanian security forces, said a news agency that often serves as a conduit for reports about the group.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Clashes Draw Support for Teachers’ Protest in Mexico
item.media:description: Mexican federal police officers clashed with teachers protesting an education overhaul and the arrest of two of their leaders in Oaxaca State on June 19.
item.description: Thousands of students in Oaxaca State have been without school for months, but after government forces clashed with demonstrators last week, a teachers’ movement appears to have gained steam.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Florida Jury Finds Former Chilean Officer Liable in ’73 Killing
item.media:description: Víctor Jara, a popular folk singer, songwriter and theater director, was murdered days after the 1973 military coup that brought Gen. Augusto Pinochet to power.
item.media:credit: Fundacion Víctor Jara, via Associated Press
item.description: A jury decided that Pedro Pablo Barrientos, a naturalized American, was behind the killing of a popular folk singer, Víctor Jara, in Chile during the coup that brought Pinochet to power.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: U.S. Investigates Whether Airstrikes Killed Taliban Hostages
item.media:description: Afghan security personnel prepared for an operation against Taliban militants in the Aliabad District of Kunduz Province earlier this month.
item.description: Afghan officials agree that the American military conducted drone strikes in a remote area dominated by the Taliban, but give widely divergent accounts of what happened.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Memo From Bangladesh: To U.S. in ’70s, a Dissenting Diplomat. To Bangladesh, ‘a True Friend.’
item.media:description: A rehearsal of the singing of Bangladesh’s national anthem on March 26, 2014, in the capital, Dhaka.
item.description: A cable by Archer K. Blood, the first ever sent through the State Department’s “dissent channel,” called on Washington to condemn its ally Pakistan’s bloody assault on Dhaka.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Seeking to Improve Ties With Russia, Turkey Apologizes for Downing Warplane
item.media:description: Turkey shot down a Russian warplane in November, saying it had violated Turkish airspace.
item.description: The same day Turkey announced a rapprochement with Israel, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan expressed regret about the downing of a Russian warplane last year.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Gay Catholic Groups Want the Vatican to Do More Than Apologize
item.media:description: Pope Francis speaking to journalists on Sunday during his flight back to Rome after a visit to Armenia.
item.description: Pope Francis’ comments about the church’s needing to apologize to gays for previous mistreatment must be followed by changes in teachings, the groups said.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Edward Snowden Criticizes ‘Big Brother’ Measure in Russia
item.description: Mr. Snowden, who took refuge in Russia after leaking classified United States data, called a Russian bill an assault on free speech.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: As Migrants Face Abuse, Fear That ‘Brexit’ Has Given License to Xenophobia
item.media:description: One poster, released during the referendum campaign by the far-right U.K. Independence Party, showed a huge line of migrants snaking into the distance and was condemned even by some members of the “Leave” side.
item.description: Amid reports of attacks and graffiti aimed at Britain’s immigrants, human rights advocates and politicians expressed alarm that the vote had unleashed simmering hatred.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: What Leaders Said Before ‘Brexit,’ and What They Say Now
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, with the Leave campaign’s bus in York, England, last month.
item.description: Political leaders on both sides of the debate are saying distinctly different things now to the promises they made before last week’s referendum.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: Kurdish Rebels Clash With Iran’s Revolutionary Guards
item.description: Kurds and Iranians have been fighting for decades on the Iraq-Iran border, a desolate area that was once the seat of a short-lived Kurdish republic.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Pro-‘Brexit’ City of Sunderland Glad to Poke Establishment in the Eye
item.media:description: Washington, a neighborhood of Sunderland, England, close to a Nissan plant. The city, a former shipbuilding center now plagued by high unemployment, voted overwhelmingly for the “Brexit.”
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Sunderland, England, a former shipbuilding center with high unemployment, voted overwhelmingly for leaving the European Union, though the city benefited from the bloc.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Economic Fears Rising, Britain Hopes to Stay in E.U. Market
item.media:description: Boris Johnson left his home in London on Monday.
item.description: Leaders on both sides of the “Brexit” debate signaled that they wanted continued access to the free-trade zone, though the European Union may have other ideas.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER, STEPHEN CASTLE and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Chinese Police Detain Activist Who Documents Labor Protests
item.description: Lu Yuyu, whom the authorities have accused of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” was taken into custody on June 16 in Dali, his friends said.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Text of Statement by George Osborne, Chancellor of Exchequer, on ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, speaking in Liverpool, England, this month.
item.description: Mr. Osborne, who is in charge of economic policy, appealed for calm before financial markets opened in London.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Worries British Cultural Institutions Facing Loss of Aid
item.media:description: Dancers formed a heart surrounded by stars to represent the European Union at the Glastonbury music festival on Sunday.
item.description: The movie industry and dance companies, in particular, expect to be affected, but there is uncertainly over what the repercussions will be.
item.dc:creator: ROSLYN SULCAS

item.title: Panama Celebrates Expanded Canal’s Successful First Passage
item.media:description: Much of the journey of a Chinese-owned container ship through the upgraded Panama Canal on Sunday was televised live.
item.description: Seventy heads of state were on hand as a container ship made it through without a hitch, though an unrelated accident involving two vessels outside the locks sent four people to a hospital.
item.dc:creator: WALT BOGDANICH

item.title: Bagdanda Journal: Demand for ‘Himalayan Viagra’ Fungus Heats Up, Maybe Too Much
item.media:description: Harvesters crawled while picking caterpillar fungus on the Tibetan Plateau in May. The caterpillar fungus, also known as yarsagumba or Himalayan Viagra, thrives in high altitudes with low temperature.
item.description: Caterpillar fungus, hailed as an aphrodisiac, can top $50,000 a pound and is an economic mainstay for mountain dwellers in Nepal, but it is becoming more scarce.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: After ‘Brexit,’ a Splitting Hangover for the City of London
item.media:description: Demonstrators at Westminster in Central London on Saturday. Many gathered to voice their opinions and show support for migrants in Britain.
item.media:credit: Marco Kesseler for The New York Times
item.description: It’s an uncertain new day for financial professionals in Britain, many of whom see “Brexit” leaving hard-won clout behind.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM and PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Election in Spain Gives Conservatives More Seats but No Mandate
item.media:description: Supporters of the Popular Party, which won the most votes Sunday in Spain’s election, outside the party’s headquarters in Madrid.
item.description: The conservative Popular Party won 137 of 350 seats in Parliament, up from 123 in the December elections but not enough to settle who will form the next government.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Pope Francis Says Church Should Apologize to Gays
item.media:description: Pope Francis spoke to journalists on the flight back to Rome after a visit to Armenia on Sunday.
item.description: The pope also said the Roman Catholic Church should ask forgiveness for the way it has treated women, for turning a blind eye to child labor and for “blessing so many weapons” in the past.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Israel and Turkey Agree to Resume Full Diplomatic Ties
item.media:description: The flags of Turkey, front, and Israel in Tel Aviv on Sunday. The two countries fell out after a deadly confrontation in 2010.
item.description: The two countries, once close regional allies, fell out after a deadly confrontation in 2010. They are scheduled to announce a deal to resume relations in Rome on Monday.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Great Britain or ‘Little England’? ‘Brexit’ Vote Revives an Old Tension
item.media:description: A souvenir stand in central London during the weekend.
item.description: As Scotland and Northern Ireland weigh the possibility of breaking with England, some British people fear the kingdom’s global power may decline.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Having Won, Some ‘Brexit’ Campaigners Begin Backpedaling
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, with the Leave campaign’s bus in York, England, last month.
item.description: Victors in Thursday’s vote to leave the European Union have begun to retreat from promises like the level of added health spending.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Volkswagen Faces Long Road Ahead, Even After a Civil Settlement
item.media:description: Marjorie Shaw, a plaintiff in in the Volkswagen class-action suit.
item.media:credit: Rachel Jerome Ferraro for The New York Times
item.description: A broad settlement that is expected to dwarf all previous deals is taking shape, but the Justice Department is still investigating criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: C.I.A. Arms for Syrian Rebels Supplied Black Market, Officials Say
item.media:description: The funeral in Rimoun, Jordan, for Anwar Abu Zaid, a police captain who was killed after he attacked a police training center in November. American and Jordanian officials said they believed that the weapons he used had been meant for a program to train Syrian rebels.
item.description: Some of the weapons linked to thefts by Jordanian intelligence operatives are believed to have been used last year to kill two Americans and three others.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and ALI YOUNES

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Surprised Hedge Fund Managers Used to Picking Winners
item.media:description: George Soros, known as the man who broke the Bank of England for his bet against the British pound in 1992, said he was confident in the strength of the “remain” camp weeks before Britain voted to exit the European Union.
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.description: George Soros, Leon Cooperman and other top investors confidently predicted that Britain would remain in the E.U. Now they’re proceeding with caution.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: The Interpreter: A Lesson From ‘Brexit’: On Immigration, Feelings Trump Facts
item.media:description: An English flag flew above a migrant camp in Calais, France, on Friday, after Britain voted to leave the European Union.
item.description: Most research shows that immigration has boosted the British economy. But evidence doesn’t vote — people do.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Chinese Activist Chen Yunfei Is to Stand Trial, Lawyer Says
item.media:description: Chen Yunfei, a Chinese political activist and artist, in Chengdu, Sichuan Province, in 2009. His sign urged Communist Party officials to disclose their assets. Mr. Chen was detained more than a year ago visiting the grave site of a victim of the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989.
item.description: Mr. Chen, an artist, has been detained for more than a year after visiting the grave site of a victim of the Tiananmen Square crackdown.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Tough Choices and Hard Lessons for E.U. After ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany will meet with leaders beginning Monday to discuss Britain’s exit from the European Union.
item.description: An altered power dynamic must be addressed as well as the question of whether to make fundamental changes or push ahead with deeper integration.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE, JIM YARDLEY and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: What in the World: Cartoons Keep Order at Japanese Construction Sites
item.media:description: Hello Kitty construction barriers lined a street this month in the Shinjuku district of Tokyo.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Road signs and traffic cones have gone “kawaii,” or cute, all over the country in an effort to entertain passers-by during commuting disturbances.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: What in the World: China Censors WeChat Rumors, Including the One About Robots Taking Over
item.description: Censorship there is well known, but bureaucrats are also focusing on more mundane matters, seeking to prevent rumors, fabricated news and superstitious premonitions from going viral.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: Will Ersatz Dollars Satisfy Cash-Starved Zimbabweans?
item.media:description: The old Zimbabwean dollar, which the government printed without restraint a decade ago.
item.description: Zimbabwe has been using the United States dollar as its currency, but those dollars have all but disappeared. Now the central bank is introducing replacement notes.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Britain to Leave Europe for a Lie
item.description: The E.U. is flawed. But the dream is noble and still worth the fight. It did not deserve to be trashed by hucksters.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Making Art From Pakistan’s Chaos
item.media:description: Detail of Imran Quershi’s installation at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, in 2013.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: The country suffers from terrorism, sectarianism and a failing government. Out of this, art blooms.
item.dc:creator: AATISH TASEER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: David Cameron’s Brexit Bust
item.description: Re-elected only a year ago, Britain’s prime minister has been swept aside by a raging torrent.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
